Tell ya what...I'll stop giving homework. We'll do all the work in the 90-minutes I have every other day with your child. No review. No homework to practice the skills taught that day. Please remember this story the next time you hear how American students are falling behind the rest of the world. While not true for all demographic groups (I know we are not allowed to say that certain groups do better than others) I think MORE emphasis on scholarly activities would do the vast majority American children a big favor.

The question I never hear asked in the homework discussion is, "When do the kids do the homework?" We have five kids and have had our share of homework ups and downs. I strongly feel that if homework is causing tears it is too much; whining is okay, but no sobbing. However sometimes the "too much" isn't the homework, but other activities. If the homework does not get started until 8 PM it doesn't take a lot to set a kid off. If our 4th grader starts his homework at 4:00 PM it takes 30 minutes. (I don't include free reading time in this.) If he starts at 8:30 PM it takes well over an hour. Sometimes I wonder if the way our school has scaled back, a move I support in principle, has only given families the opportunity to load up their kids in other areas and in the end does not result in more unstructured, less stressful free time for kids. Many of the kids in my son's 4th grade class play on three sports teams at the same time.

A warm-up that brings someone to 95% of maximum heart rate is not a warm-up as "traditionally" recommended - it is a workout. The usual warm-up is about 5 minutes of sub-maximal movement similar to the activity you are about to do.  Neither educated fitness enthusiasts nor trainers would recommend a warm-up that goes past 70% intensity level.  The study is flawed.

Ottmar Edenhofer, the co chairman of Working Group 3 of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change for the fifth assessment, sent this note:

he criticisms by McIntyre and Lynas relate to the headline of the press release that was drafted by the WGIII and the Secretariat and that accompanied the publication of the SRREN SPM on 9th May. It is important to note that the press release put the 80% figure into perspective:

"Over 160 [164] existing scientific scenarios on the possible penetration of renewables by 2050, alongside environmental and social implications, have been reviewed with four analyzed in-depth. These four were chosen in order to represent the full range. [...]

The most optimistic of the four, in-depth scenarios projects renewable energy accounting for as much as 77 percent of the world‘s energy demand by 2050, amounting to about 314 of 407 Exajoules per year. [...]

77 percent is up from just under 13 percent of the total primary energy supply of around 490 Exajoules in 2008. Each of the scenarios is underpinned by a range of variables such as changes in energy efficiency, population growth and per capita consumption. These lead to varying levels of total primary energy supply in 2050, with the lowest of the four scenarios seeing renewable energy accounting for a share of 15 percent in 2050, based on a total primary energy supply of 749 Exajoules."

Sven Teske was nominated as an author by the German government and selected by the WGIII as Lead author in the IPCC's continuous effort to draw on the full range of expertise, and this includes NGOs and business as well as academia. Chapter 10 has been thouroughly reviewed by independent experts and governments. He is one of nine Lead Authors, with two Coordinating Lead Authors overseeing the process of writing the chapter. He has made substantial contributions, but was neither the only nor the leading person in this team effort.

Kind regards,

Ottmar Edenhofer

--
Professor Dr. Ottmar Edenhofer

Co-chair Working Group III, IPCC

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2009/09/hey-ya-mal/

I told Steve and his buddy Anthony Watts that they should move to Sri Lanka, since they have been
so humiliated by actual working climate scientists. At least Watts picked the right target in his failed attempt to discredit the temperature data.

McIntyre is his own kettle of fish. His blog consists of constant attacks on climate scientists, based on arcane statistical terms, strange variance analyses, and tree ring analysis that has long been shown to be false and irrelevant. Scientists I know hate him, since his relentless attacks- chimed in on by his blog's comment section- are based on..... nothing. Steve is like a geeky graduate student who was jilted by his girlfriend years ago, and can't keep from writing her crank letters.

As for the specific issue being discussed today, Steve has a point, but as usual it's irrelevant. It's not possible to predict the percentage of renewable energy market penetration in 2050, so every prediction- whether 20 or 80%- is speculative. IPCC only listed a range of possibilities, but putting numbers on them was indeed marginal science. The authors admitted as much. Smelling blood, McIntyre jumped on IPCC in general, and threw in a little guilt by association with the Greenpeace connection. This is an emotional appeal disguised in Mc's jargon, in the same way that they like to repeat "Al Gore", "alarmist", or even "World government". A joke, in other words.

Lynas is a journalist, and his opinion doesn't count.

By giving McIntyre legitimacy, you are contributing to the plummeting reputation of the New York Times on this most important issue.

We should understand that the lack of man-made climate change never-the-less does not end the need to alter our consumption of fossil fuels. There are MANY very good reasons to do so - starting with the annual payment of some $450 billion to purchase foreign oil. Adopting less fossil consuming vehicles built domestically grows JOBS, strengthens local economies and enhances energy security.

It remains an astonishment that conservatives like Rush and O'Reilly have yet to grok the positive effect from electrifying light transport. JOBS, JOBS oh and... JOBS Bill! Hamtramck in Detroit has already added two new shifts to build GM's hybrid cars. And how about building a nation that can supply its own energy?? DOE reports we have enough overnight electric capacity to charge 100M electric vehicles - without adding a single power plant. Can you say "Energy Security" Rush??

Climate action is meaningless. What does mean something is ending addiction to foreign oil. Growing new markets and manufacturing base in the transport, construction and energy fields... and putting some of the $450B back into local economies. How about that? Think global, act local. The green mantra applied to real world issues.
